title: A model of an atom which contains 24 electrons, 25 protons, and 26 neutrons has some of its particles inside a nucleus at the centre of the model. What is the nucleon number (mass number) of the atom? - Quora

response.answer_text: If there are not as many electrons as protons, then it is an ION, or ionized atom. When you just say “atom” that is referring to the neutral atom. The atomic number is the number of protons in the nucleus and it defines which chemical element it is. The mass number is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons. The atomic mass is the mass of one mole of the atoms in isotopic proportion as they normally exist on Earth. The different possible isotopes have the same number of protons, but different numbers of neutrons. The protons an neutrons are always inside the nucleus. The electrons exist as wave/particle dualities in orbitals around the nucleus.

WEll, [math]\text{mass number} \equiv 25+ 26 \equiv 51[/math], i.e. the SUM of the massive nuclear particles, protons, and neutrons… We can further specify the identity of the isotope, and its charge, as [math]^{51}Mn^{+}[/math]. How can we do this?
